column4: I think grub-install in ubuntu 10.04 is semi-broken. The "fix grub" option in the install cd dosn't do the right thing either.
It works for me
me too usually. But I'm getting it installed with the wrong "prefix" set in grub.
what's your machine config
the wrong prefix? Elaborate
I'm running in vmware. One ext2 /boot and ext4 / on LVM. I cloned this system from another server
after installing grub, "prefix" is set to (hd0,1)/boot/grub in grub-prompt. But the correct value would be (hd0,1)/grub
/boot/grub is the standard location. why do you want to put it under /grub?
since "/boot" is a seperat partition, it is a folder on the "root" partition, not the "boot" partition
(hd0,1) is the boot partition, not the root-partition.
whye is there a root-partion
you need a root-partition to be able to run Linux
yes, yes. but it is invariably also the boot partion. Except for you
so are you saying that having a seperate /boot partition is not supported?
I am sying you are doing something the designeres never contemplated

then the designers are retarted. That has been a preferred way of doing it for many users for ages. It is also supposed to be supported by the install process, and works fine when configuring it under install.
that may be true.
but there you have it. Complain to Canonical.
are you sure about this?
I am now. This isn't my call though
thanks for the input. I'm however not convinced that is the case.
but reporting the issue I'm experiencing is probably a good idea anyway.

I get the same error when I try without a seperate boot partition (I copied files from /boot), then I removed the filesystem on it, and set the "/"-partition to boot in "parted", then I did "dpkg-reconfigure grub-pc", and then "grub-install /dev/sda" and "update-grub". I noticed grub produced new grub.cfg which refers to the lvm-root as root-volume.
